comments.commentBody: Assuming the government will protect you from your bad employer is a mistake. The government is responsible for setting the entire process in motion and will neither create nor enforce laws contravening the pro-business status quo.

Good point. The first season all three networks broadcast all prime-time shows in color was 1966-67. In 1968, NBC estimated that only 25 percent of American households owned color TVs.

It looks like capitalism doesn't work for the vast majority of people in this country either. If it did, there would be no need for a minimum wage. There would be a shortage of workers,and a steady rise in income for all workers.

I moved to Hampton Roads from the Left Coast 7 years ago, largely driven by cost of living. Within one year, my landlords were raising the rent to the same amount I paid in SoCal. I wound up moving into a cheap, sweltering, smoky Southern shoebox and screwing up my health. But I've since met quite a few military families who served in Germany; some are moving back when their service is up. As one put it, Europeans work to live, Americans live to work.

You may think you are helping the needy by raising the minimum wage but you are in fact harming them. Its the fatal flaw of socialism. You are robbing a person of the need to progress and improve themselves. Socialism is a terrible thing that always fails in the end. And its victims are people who could have been much more.

That $15 an hour sounds pretty good compared to CUNY adjunct pay, right? Hourly, I am sure most adjuncts earn less than that unless they are able to do all their grading by Scantron and never revise anything in their courses from semester to semester.

Why not do both?

And reduce taxes on who exactly? The so called job creators who've seen their taxes reduced for the last 30+ years with no explosion in good paying jobs? Keep drinking that 'supply side' kool-aid.

But those jobs are stepping stones.  Younger folks living with parents or roommates are supposed to start out in such positions and advance forward with experience and training (education in this case not always required per se).    In American capitalism, we are supposed to earn our wages as we earn our position in life.  A living wage implies that you are living within your means for what you're making, and if not, it is not always pay that is the single culprit. I recall reading about a man who pays $400/mo to live in a cardboard box in a friends apartment in San Francisco.  If he must live like that, then it's the city he chose to live in that could easily be to blame, regardless of wages.  I lived in NYC once and now live very comfortably in scenic Montana for less than I was making in Brooklyn a year ago.

A danger more than terrorism? Like a terrorist setting off a nuclear bomb? That's silly. One result of a 2 degree Celcius and 3 meter sea level rise is higher agricultural productivity and land prices in Canada and Russia. What would you rather have? A nuclear bomb go off in NYC or 3 meter sea level rise. Central Park in NYC is 30 meters above sea level. Go look at Google earth. A 3 meter sea level rise above current has happened before, around 100K years ago, and homo sapiens survived.

"Like a terrorist setting off a nuclear bomb?"

That's silly.

It is a fantasy danger, used to ignore a real danger.

We can do no more than try.  Heroes are frequently those who keep on fighting when the battle seems to be lost.  No matter how distant the goal, the first step is small one.  Your concept strikes me as analogous to man who asks his friend if he can borrow 20 bucks.  The friend  says no.  So the man then says, How about 100?  You may be correct, but the smaller solutions may buy us time to figure out the larger ones.

Yes, this is a clear and present danger of enormous importance, far more than terrorism or anything else on the international agenda. Cities will drown. Crops will fail. Nations will face ruin.

But this Editorial is still in denial, indulging in fantasy as much as those who deny the whole problem. "If carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels continue unabated, the vast West Antarctic ice sheet could . . ."

No. There is no remedial action currently under discussion that could prevent that. The goals of abating carbon emissions would not save us.

It is too late for that. It has already gone too far. We accepted as inevitable enough warming to bring this on.

The 2 degrees Centigrade that is the goal equals 3.6 degrees F. as we use it here. Recent work on ancient warmer climates suggests that average produces higher at the poles where all the ice is now, and lower where we live.

We ought to do something about this. Just limiting the rise of CO2 isn't going to do it. We can't even do that much, when it isn't enough, so nobody even talks about what we really need to do.

There is science on alternatives. There are actually quite a few. I'm not going to try in a few characters to present a "best choice." I'm saying we must face that our current efforts, things we can't even do, would not be enough even if we did them all. Pretending they could fix this is as much denial as any Republican.

We need to think bigger. Much bigger.

Every opera I ever chorus-mastered or sang in had a memorable sitzprobe, especially since the home of the sitzprobe at my university job was my own chorus room (luckily, large enough for the works to fit snugly). They're such an important step in the process.

My favorite was our Fledermaus, with Theodore Bikel "in the haus." He passed away just last summer.

Larry.  You speak as if all the businesses in NY are in non-trade able sectors ion the economy.  I work at a manufacturing plant in Rockland county.  Our company competes against others that have their factories in Malaysia and China.  When the minimum wage prices these jobs out of the area I'll invite you to come explain to all the laid off employees your simplistic view of how an economy  works.

The truth is that although companies complain that they will have to cut jobs and that it will cost too much to run a business,the real truth is that once $15.00 is the minimum wage, these same companies will go up in the prices they charge. The cost of a loaf of bread will increase. Every Company that is complaining will try to get a piece of that $15.00.  The fact that this will be done, along with rents increasing,  will make it very much like a dog chasing its tail.  Companies may complain, but they will increase their cost because there is more money out there to get, not because they are paying more for employees. Companies have never  hired more employees than they needed. This will not change even with the increased profit.

In your scenario, you are going to give minimum wage (by end of 2018, we are still 30 or so months away) and increase prices. You are not at any loss. As a consumer, I may end up paying more for my pizza, but it is going to mean that the Govt. is going to dole out less for welfare and social services. That in turn is going to ensure public infrastructure projects and services such as schools get funded better. Win for everyone as I see it (including you!).
